results.title: Raising Victor Vargas
results.creator_credit: Peter Sollett, Scott Macaulay, Robin O'hara, Alain de la Mata and Studio Canal
results.brief_description: Victor (Victor Rasuk) a New York City teenager gets caught trying to sleep with ‘Fat Donna’ when his younger sister Vicki (Krystal Rodriguez) realises what he’s up to and spreads the word in the neighbourhood. Victor, thinking his reputation has suffered a blow, quells the summer heat with a visit to the local public pool with his best friend Harold. Here he meets ‘Juicy Judy’ (Judy Marte) and he decides to pursue her. Living in a small apartment with his strict Grandmother, sister and piano-playing younger brother Nino (Rasuk’s real-life brother Silvestre), Victor finds life as a teenager challenging when he gets the blame for having a bad influence on his siblings. Coming-of-age is tough (and sometimes comical) for Victor as he finds real love, gets a glimpse of what manhood is about and asserts his place within the family. Based on the short film “Five Feet High and Rising” by its writer/director Peter Sollett. Cast also includes Kevin Rivera, Altagracia Guzman, Melonie Diaz.

results.title: Raising the standard
results.creator_credit: John Spencer, James Carr, British Productivity Council and World Wide
results.brief_description: Discusses the British standard of living and relates it to productivity and ways in which both may be improved. Reorganising of work is essential, and problems involved are shown. The most important of these is the attitude and, not infrequently, the opposition of workers. There is a greater need for tactful handling of problems on the part of management. Labor must realise that more work, which leads to increased productivity, means higher standard of living and not simply higher profits and dividends. The film concludes with a discussion on these points.

results.title: Raise the red lantern
results.creator_credit: Zhang Yimou, Fu-Sheng Chiu, China Film and Era International
results.brief_description: On the death of her father Songlian is forced to leave her University studies and becomes the fourth concubine to a rich man. She enters a world in which a rigid ancestral code dictates the day to day existence of the four wives. Every night a red lantern is raised outside the boudoir of the wife who will be “graced” with the husband’s sexual favours. The women, though equally unhappy, are further divided by the competition to give birth to a son. The beautiful palatial house in which the women are enclosed slowly loses its allure as the closed, hermetic world in which the women exist is revealed as a physical and emotional prison. The ravishing cinematography and set design is itself a symbolic commentary on the abuses of power involved in the maintenance of “ancestral privilege”. As the seasons pass Songlian is stripped of her humanity, dignity and her power. Based on the novel “Wives and Concubines” by Su Tong. Gong Li stars as Songlian. This film was perceived as an attack on the Chinese establishment and banned although elsewhere, it was widely acclaimed and earned an Oscar nomination for Best Foreign Film. Winner of the Silver Lion at Venice Film Festival, 1992. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Rapt
results.brief_description:
A virtual body built from Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans of the artist’s body. MRI scans map the water content of the body to produce axial slices. These scans were used to create a 3D body accessible on any plane, making it possible to navigate through the body, and to view it internally and externally.

(Special thanks to Ray Scan Imaging and The Childrens’ Hospital Westmead Sydney)

results.title: Rapeseed Your Alternative Crop
results.brief_description: As wheat crops decrease in value Rapeseed farming is flourishing. This video examines not only the financial advantages of Rapeseed crops, but also those apparent to the wheat growing industry when crops of wheat are grown in paddocks where Rapeseed was produced the previous year. Not only does a higher yield occur, a 30% increase is evident, but there are less weeds, insects and wheat root diseases, the cycle of the latter having actually been broken by the planting of Rapeseed the previous year.

results.title: Rape: a crime of war (D)
results.creator_credit: Shelley Saywell, Silva Basmajian and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Throughout history, the rape of innocent women during war time has been a common, but hidden occurrence; it is only now that an international court, The Hague, is trying to convict someone for rape as a war crime. This video follows four women who courageously recount their stories of rape and confinement in Bosnia during the recent conflict. It also conducts interviews with the legal personnel behind The Hague Trial. Archival footage from hearings in Nuremberg, Nanking, Rwanda and Bosnia are interspersed with images of Western art and culture which present a confusing portrayal of rape and attempt to legitimize rape during war time as an inevitable outcome. Previewing is recommended.

results.title: Rape. Part 2. Providing the proof
results.creator_credit: Richard Siegel, Richard Cullather, Karen Smith and AIMS Instructional Media
results.brief_description: Deals with the preservation of corroborating evidence in the investigation of rape. Offers information on procedures, the establishment of fact, the collection and analysis of demonstrative evidence, the chain of possession, identification procedures and protection for the victim.

results.title: Rape culture
results.creator_credit: Renner Wunderlich, Margaret Margaret Lazarus and Cambridge Documentary Films
results.brief_description: This film explores those elements in our society which contribute to the ideology that supports rape. It attempts to expand our society’s narrow and sexist concept of rape and establishes the connections between violence and “normal” patterns of male-female behaviour. Includes the opinions of convicted rapists, rape crisis centre workers, and others associated with the problem.

results.title: Rap race and equality
results.creator_credit: Grant Elliott, Stephen Elliott, Burberry Productions and Elliott Productions
results.brief_description: Rap and hip-hop were musical genres that developed within the African-American subcultures of America’s largest cities. Fusing funk, disco and a do-it-yourself punk aesthetic, rap music quickly became the defining voice of a generation of young, angry and disenfranchised black youth. In this incisive documentary, the history of rap and hip-hop is explored as well as the larger social context of American race and class relations. Interviews with Ice-T, Queen latifah, KRS-One, Chuck D and Rakim explore the context of rap’s evolution and offer necessary defences of the music’s relevance and importance to African-American youth; especially in the context of a popular media that has often dismissed rap as misogynist or “inauthentic”. Made by two Australian brothers who fell in love with the music, this documentary gives a voice to the power, impact, originality and importance of rap and hip-hop.
